chapters.chapterTitle: Water to Wine and Temple Cleansing

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read John 2:1-22 aloud, focusing on the dialogue between Jesus and the mother of Jesus in verses 3-4 and the temple cleansing in verses 12-16.
tips: Notice the repeated phrase 'woman' (v.4) showing Jesus' authority
Pay attention to the contrast between the wedding crisis and temple corruption
Listen for the emotional shift from the wedding to Jerusalem

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO is involved, WHAT happens, WHERE it occurs, and WHY Jesus performs these actions.
tips: Include the wedding at Cana and the water-to-wine transformation
Note the temple cleansing in Jerusalem
Describe Jesus' statement about his body being the true temple (v.21)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the mother of Jesus' request for wine (v.3), Jesus' command to fill jars (v.6), or the temple cleansing (v.12-16)?
tips: The mother of Jesus' bold request shows her faith in Jesus' provision
The simple command 'fill the jars with water' reveals Jesus' power to transform ordinary things
The temple cleansing demonstrates Jesus' authority to purify religious systems

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was John trying to communicate to all believers through this passage?
tips: Jesus reveals His glory through tangible signs (water-to-wine)
He establishes His body as the true temple that will be raised after three days
The passage shows Jesus' authority to cleanse both physical and spiritual corruption

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The water-to-wine event? The temple cleansing? Jesus' statement about the temple of his body?
tips: The phrase 'destroy this temple' (v.19) refers to the physical temple but Jesus means his body (the church) will be raised
The temple was used for commercial activities that corrupted worship
The water-to-wine event was a sign of Jesus' glory and new covenant provision

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply this week's lesson from the water-to-wine event to a situation where you feel things are running out?
tips: Identify a current need where you feel 'water' (insufficiency) is running out
Pray for Jesus to transform your circumstances into His provision (wine)
This week, remove sin and idolatry from your life as Jesus did in the temple

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for providing His grace in unexpected ways (like the water-to-wine) and ask for the courage to cleanse your life of sin (like the temple cleansing).
tips: Thank God for turning your 'water' (current circumstances) into His 'wine' (provision)
Pray for strength to remove sin and idolatry from your life
Ask Jesus to be the true temple in your life (v.21)

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read John 3:1-16 aloud, focusing on the dialogue between Jesus and Nicodemus in verses 4-8 and the wind metaphor in verse 8.
tips: Notice the repetition of 'born again' (v.3, v.5)
Pay attention to the contrast between physical birth and spiritual birth (v.6)
The wind metaphor (v.8) illustrates the Spirit's invisible yet powerful work

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (Nicodemus and Jesus), WHAT (Jesus explains the need for spiritual rebirth), WHERE (by night), and WHY (Nicodemus seeks understanding of entering God's kingdom).
tips: Include that Nicodemus is a ruler of the Jews (v.1)
Note the threefold explanation: born again (v.3), born of water and Spirit (v.5), and the wind metaphor (v.8)
The connection to the serpent (v.14) and the cross (v.16)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: Jesus' definition of being born again (v.3), the wind metaphor (v.8), or the connection to the serpent (v.14).
tips: The wind metaphor (v.8) shows the Spirit's work is invisible yet powerful, explaining why we don't see spiritual rebirth
The connection to the serpent (v.14) foreshadows Christ's crucifixion as the means of salvation (Numbers 21)
The statement 'Unless one is born of water and the Spirit' (v.5) is the clearest definition of spiritual rebirth

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was John trying to communicate about the necessity of spiritual rebirth and its connection to Christ's death?
tips: John emphasizes that spiritual rebirth is essential for entering God's kingdom (v.3-5)
The cross (v.14-16) is the means by which this rebirth occurs through Christ's death and resurrection
God's love for the world motivates the sending of His Son (v.16)

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The meaning of 'born again', the wind metaphor, and the serpent connection.
tips: 'Born again' refers to spiritual rebirth by the Holy Spirit, not physical birth (v.3-5)
The wind metaphor (v.8) illustrates the invisible, yet powerful work of the Spirit
The serpent in the wilderness (v.14) is a type of Christ's crucifixion, where the lifting of the serpent healed the Israelites (Numbers 21)

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply the concept of being born again by the Holy Spirit this week? Consider what you need to surrender to the Spirit's work.
tips: Pray for the Holy Spirit to work in your life to bring about spiritual rebirth (v.5)
Reflect on what you need to let go of to receive the new birth (like the wind blowing without being seen)
Read John 3:5 and ask God to help you understand the Spirit's work in you

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray for God to give you a new birth by the Holy Spirit and to help you understand the connection to Christ's crucifixion.
tips: Thank God for the new birth that comes through Jesus (v.16)
Ask the Holy Spirit to work in your life to bring about spiritual rebirth (v.5)
Pray for the courage to accept Christ's death and resurrection as the means of your salvation

chapters.chapterTitle: Healing at the Pool and the Son's Authority

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read John 5:1-9, 16-18 aloud, paying attention to the dialogue between Jesus and the paralyzed man (verses 1-9) and the Sabbath argument (verses 16-18).
tips: Notice the man's plea: 'I have no one to put me into the pool when the water is stirred up' (v. 4)
Pay attention to Jesus' command: 'Get up, take up your bed, and walk' (v. 8)
Notice the contrast in Jesus' statement about the Sabbath: 'My Father is working until now, and I am working' (v. 17)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO is healed, WHAT Jesus does, WHERE it happens, and WHY it matters to believers.
tips: The man who had been paralyzed for 38 years (v. 1-2)
Jesus commands him to get up and walk (v. 8)
The Jews' reaction on the Sabbath (v. 16-18)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the man's long-term disability (v. 1-2), Jesus' immediate healing (v. 8), or the Son's claim of authority over the Sabbath (v. 17-18)?
tips: The man's 38 years of paralysis highlights the depth of his need and the cost of healing
Jesus' command to 'get up, take up your bed, and walk' shows authority over physical and spiritual condition
The Son's statement: 'the Son can do nothing of his own accord, but only what he sees the Father doing' (v. 16) reveals the unity of the Father and Son

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was John trying to communicate to all believers through this passage about the Son's authority and healing?
tips: John emphasizes that Jesus, as the Son, is the one who works as the Father (v. 17) and has the authority to heal and give life
This passage shows that the Son's work (healing) is part of the Father's work (v. 17) and that the Son has the authority to judge (v. 27)
The healing on the Sabbath demonstrates that Jesus is not bound by the Sabbath law but works in accordance with the Father's will

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The healing on the Sabbath, the Son's claim of authority, or the concept of the Son giving life?
tips: The Sabbath conflict: Jesus heals on the Sabbath, but the Jews argue that it's unlawful to move a bed (v. 16-18). This shows the tension between Jewish law and Jesus' authority
The phrase 'the Son can do nothing of his own accord' (v. 16) might seem to limit Jesus' power, but it emphasizes that all his actions flow from the Father's will
The concept of the Son giving life to whom He wills (v. 21) is a unique claim that sets Jesus apart from other religious figures

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply the Son's authority to heal and give life in your life this week?
tips: Identify a situation where you feel stuck or paralyzed (like the man's 38 years) and pray for the Son's healing power
Practice trusting that the Son gives life to whom He wills (v. 21) by surrendering areas of your life to Him
Ask for the courage to act in ways that honor the Son's authority, even when it challenges cultural norms

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for the Son's authority to heal and give life, and ask for the courage to trust Him in difficult circumstances.
tips: Thank God that Jesus, as the Son, works as the Father does (v. 17)
Pray for the strength to heal the brokenness in your life through Christ
Ask for the wisdom to understand when the Son is working in your life to give life (v. 21)

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read John 7:35-38 aloud, paying attention to the contrast between the physical and spiritual.
tips: Notice the phrase 'If anyone thirsts, let him come to me and drink' (v.37)
Pay attention to the word 'rivers' (plural) indicating abundance and life
The phrase 'out of his heart' suggests an internal transformation

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO Jesus is speaking to, WHAT he says, WHERE this happens, and WHY it matters.
tips: Include the context of the Feast of Booths (last day of the festival)
Note that Jesus is speaking to the crowd of people at the temple
The promise of the Spirit (rivers of living water) for believers

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: Jesus' invitation to the thirsty (v.37), the promise of rivers of living water (v.38), or the contrast between the physical and spiritual?
tips: The invitation 'If anyone thirsts, let him come to me and drink' is direct and urgent
The promise of 'rivers of living water' is a powerful image of abundant spiritual life
The phrase 'out of his heart' shows an internal transformation that happens in believers

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was John trying to communicate to all believers through this passage about the coming of the Spirit and Jesus' role as the source of life?
tips: John emphasizes that Jesus is the one who provides the living water (the Spirit) for believers
This passage shows that the believer's life is transformed by the Spirit, not by human effort
The promise of the Spirit comes after Jesus' death and resurrection (as the 'rivers of living water')

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The meaning of 'rivers of living water', the timing of Jesus' 'time' vs. the Spirit's coming, or the Feast of Booths context?
tips: The phrase 'rivers of living water' is a metaphor for the Holy Spirit, which is given to believers after Jesus' death and resurrection
Jesus says 'my time has not yet come' (v.16) meaning the time of his death and resurrection has not arrived, but he is speaking about the future Spirit
The Feast of Booths is a Jewish festival of harvest and fellowship, but Jesus uses it to point to the spiritual renewal that comes through him

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you 'come to Jesus' (v.37) this week when you feel spiritually thirsty?
tips: Identify a time when you feel empty or spiritually dry and seek Jesus
Ask for the Holy Spirit to bring life to your heart (rivers of living water)
Trust that Jesus' promise of the Spirit will transform your life

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray for the Holy Spirit to fill you with the living water of Jesus.
tips: Thank God for the promise of the Spirit (rivers of living water) in your life
Ask for the courage to come to Jesus when you are thirsty
Pray for the Spirit to work in your heart to bring life and transformation

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read John 9:1-41 aloud, paying attention to the dialogue between Jesus and the man in verses 1-16, and the Pharisees' reactions in verses 17-41.
tips: Notice the phrase 'It was not that this man sinned, or his parents, but that the works of God might be displayed in him' (v.3)
Pay attention to the contrast between the man's physical blindness and the Pharisees' spiritual blindness (v.38-41)
Notice the repeated phrase 'he is blind' (v.1, 3, 18, 39) and 'he has seen' (v.34, 41)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (Jesus, the blind man, the Pharisees) does WHAT (heals the blind man, questions the man's sight, testifies), WHERE (in Jerusalem, at the pool of Siloam), and WHY (to display God's works and reveal spiritual blindness).
tips: Jesus heals the man born blind by making mud and having him wash in the pool of Siloam (v.6-7)
The blind man's testimony to the Pharisees (v.39-41) shows his transformation
The Pharisees' rejection of Jesus' authority (v.39-41) highlights their spiritual blindness

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: Jesus' declaration about the man's blindness (v.3), the man's response to Jesus' healing (v.7), or the Pharisees' accusation about the Sabbath (v.14)?
tips: Jesus' statement 'It was not that this man sinned, or his parents, but that the works of God might be displayed in him' (v.3) - shows God's purpose in the blindness
The man's immediate response: 'Go, wash in the pool of Siloam' (v.7) - demonstrates faith in action
Jesus' final words: 'If you were blind, you would have no guilt; but now that you say, We see, your guilt remains' (v.39) - a profound contrast between physical and spiritual sight

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was John trying to communicate to all believers through this passage?
tips: John emphasizes that true sight comes from Christ, not from human efforts or religious rules
The passage reveals that spiritual blindness (the Pharisees) is a result of rejecting Christ, while physical blindness (the man) is healed by Christ's work
Christ is the Light of the World (v.5) who reveals truth and heals the blind

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The man's blindness from birth, why Jesus didn't immediately heal the man's eyes, or the Pharisees' accusation about the Sabbath?
tips: The phrase 'born blind' (v.1) is not about sin but about God's purpose to display His works (v.3) - this challenges the idea that suffering is always due to sin
The use of 'Sabbath' (v.14) by the Pharisees is a cultural reference to Jewish law, but Jesus is not violating the Sabbath - He is revealing a deeper truth about God's authority
The term 'works of God' (v.3) refers to God's purpose in the life of the man, not to human deeds - this is a key theological concept in John's theology

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply the theme of spiritual blindness and the need for Christ's healing in your life this week?
tips: Reflect on a situation where you are 'spiritually blind' (not seeing the need for Christ) and ask God to open your eyes
Pray for the gift of sight (both physical and spiritual) when you are in a dark place
Share your experience of Christ healing you (like the man) with someone who is blind (physically or spiritually)

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for the healing of the blind man and ask for spiritual sight.
tips: Thank God that He heals the blind (both physical and spiritual) through Jesus
Pray for courage to see the truth of Christ in your life and the lives of others
Ask God to help you become a light to those who are blind

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read John 10:1-18 aloud, paying attention to the repetition of 'I am the door' (v. 9) and 'I am the good shepherd' (v. 11, 14).
tips: Notice the repetition of 'I am the door' (v. 9) and 'I am the good shepherd' (v. 11, 14) for emphasis
Pay attention to the contrast between the thief (v. 10) and the shepherd (v. 11)
The phrase 'I know my own and my own know me' (v. 14) is a key expression of intimate relationship

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, summarize WHO the shepherd is, WHAT the shepherd does, WHERE the sheep are, and WHY the shepherd lays down his life.
tips: The Good Shepherd (Jesus) leads his sheep by name (v. 3)
The sheep hear His voice and follow Him (v. 4)
The shepherd lays down his life for the sheep (v. 15)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: 'I am the door' (v. 9), 'I know my own' (v. 14), or 'I lay down my life' (v. 15)?
tips: The door metaphor (v. 9) shows that Jesus is the only way to salvation, which is a profound theological claim
The intimate knowledge of the sheep by name (v. 14) reveals the personal and relational nature of Christ's care
The act of laying down one's life (v. 15) points to the ultimate sacrifice of Jesus

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was John trying to communicate to all believers through this passage?
tips: John emphasizes that Jesus is the only way to salvation (the door) and the one who knows and cares for His sheep personally
The passage shows that Jesus' identity as the Good Shepherd (who lays down his life) is central to the believer's life and salvation

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The concept of the 'door', the 'other sheep' (v. 16), or the statement that Jesus and the Father are one (v. 30)?
tips: The 'door' metaphor (v. 9) is a unique way to express that Jesus is the only way to salvation, which contrasts with other religious paths
The 'other sheep' (v. 16) refers to believers from other groups (e.g., Gentiles) who will eventually be brought into the one flock
The statement 'I and the Father are one' (v. 30) is a claim of divine unity that some might find difficult to grasp in a historical context

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply the idea that Jesus is the Good Shepherd who lays down his life for you this week?
tips: Spend time with God this week, just as the sheep hear the shepherd's voice (v. 4)
Pray for the courage to follow Jesus as the only way (the door) when faced with difficult decisions
Consider how Jesus laid down his life for you and ask for the strength to do the same for others

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for being the Good Shepherd who knows you and lays down his life for you.
tips: Thank God that He knows your name and cares for you personally
Ask for the strength to follow Jesus as the only way to salvation
Pray for the courage to lay down your life for others, just as Jesus did

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read John 11:1-44 aloud, paying attention to the dialogue between Jesus and Martha in verses 23-27.
tips: Notice the phrase 'I am the resurrection and the life' (v.25) repeated for emphasis
Observe the emotional shift from Martha's grief to her declaration of faith
Pay attention to Jesus' weeping in verse 35 as a sign of His deep compassion

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, summarize WHO is involved, WHAT happens, WHERE it occurs, and WHY Jesus raises Lazarus.
tips: Include the sisters Mary and Martha sending word about Lazarus' illness (v.1-2)
Note Jesus' statement that Lazarus has 'fallen asleep' (v.11) but will rise again (v.25)
Describe the resurrection of Lazarus after four days (v.43-44)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: Jesus' declaration 'I am the resurrection and the life' (v.25), Martha's initial doubt (v.21-22), or Jesus' weeping (v.35)?
tips: Jesus' weeping (v.35) shows His empathy for human grief and the reality of death
The phrase 'I am the resurrection and the life' (v.25) is a powerful declaration of Christ's authority over death
Martha's quick response to Jesus' statement about resurrection (v.27) demonstrates her growing faith

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was John trying to communicate to all believers through this passage about Jesus' identity and power?
tips: John emphasizes that Jesus is the source of eternal life and the one who overcomes death
This passage shows that belief in Jesus leads to life even after death (v.25-26)
It contrasts the temporary nature of human life with the eternal life that comes through Christ

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The phrase 'fallen asleep' for death? Why Jesus weeps? The resurrection after four days?
tips: 'Fallen asleep' is a metaphor used by Jesus for death (v.11) to comfort the disciples, but it does not mean Lazarus is dead
Jesus weeping (v.35) is a sign of His deep emotional connection to human suffering and the reality of death
The four-day wait for resurrection (v.39) shows that Jesus' power is not limited by time and that death is not the final word

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply Jesus' declaration that 'I am the resurrection and the life' to your current situation this week?
tips: Identify a situation where you feel 'dead' (spiritually or physically) and trust Jesus to bring life
Pray for the courage to face death (both physical and spiritual) with hope in Christ
Spend time in prayer this week asking for the strength to live as a resurrection person

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray about Jesus being the resurrection and the life, and how His power transforms our lives.
tips: Thank God for Jesus' power to overcome death and bring eternal life
Ask for the grace to weep with Him in our grief
Pray for the strength to believe that even in death, Jesus' resurrection life is available to us

chapters.chapterTitle: The Triumphal Entry and the Hour Has Come

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read John 12:1-18 aloud, focusing on the emotional tension of the anointing scene (v.1-3) and the crowd's triumphant response (v.12-15).
tips: Notice the repetition of 'the hour has come' (v.23-24)
Pay attention to the contrast between Mary's action (v.3) and Judas's complaint (v.4)
Listen for the crowd's cry of 'Hosanna' (v.13) and the phrase 'the Son of Man' (v.24)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO is involved, WHAT happens, WHERE it occurs, and WHY it matters.
tips: Include Mary anointing Jesus with nard (v.3)
Note the crowd's cry of 'Hosanna' and the palm branches (v.13-15)
Describe Jesus' statement about the grain of wheat and the hour (v.23-24)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the anointing (v.3), the crowd's response (v.13-15), or Jesus' declaration about the hour (v.23-24)?
tips: The anointing with nard is a costly act that foreshadows Jesus' burial (v.3)
The crowd's cry of 'Hosanna' shows their recognition of Jesus as the King of Israel (v.13)
Jesus' statement about the grain of wheat (v.24) reveals the necessity of His death for abundant fruit

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was John trying to communicate to all believers through this passage?
tips: John shows that Jesus' death is necessary for the fulfillment of His mission (as the grain of wheat that dies to bear fruit)
He reveals that Jesus will be lifted up (crucified) and draw all people to Himself
This passage connects the anointing to the coming sacrifice, showing that Jesus' death is the means of salvation

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are confusing? The anointing for burial, the 'hour has come' meaning, or the concept of being 'lifted up'?
tips: The anointing with nard was a costly perfume typically used for burial (v.3), but here it's for Jesus' life, foreshadowing His death
The phrase 'the hour has come' (v.23) refers to the time when Jesus must die to accomplish His mission of redemption
Being 'lifted up' (v.24) is a metaphor for Jesus' crucifixion and resurrection, which draws all people to Him

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply the concept of 'the hour has come' to your life this week?
tips: Consider an area where you feel God's will is being fulfilled through your sacrifice (like the grain of wheat that dies to bear fruit)
Think about what you need to surrender to God in the next week, trusting that His death brings life
Practice a specific act of obedience that reflects the 'hour has come' for your life

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God that He has come to the hour of His sacrifice and that He draws us to Himself.
tips: Thank God that Jesus' death is the means of drawing you to Him
Ask for the courage to surrender your life to His purpose
Pray for the Holy Spirit to help you understand the 'hour' in your life

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read John 14:1-14 aloud, paying attention to the emotional tone of Jesus' reassurance and the dialogue with Thomas and Philip.
tips: Note the repeated phrase 'Let not your hearts be troubled' (v13)
Pay attention to Thomas' question: 'Lord, we do not know where you are going. How can we know the way?' (v5)
Notice the emphasis on 'I am the way, and the truth, and the life' (v11)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO Jesus is speaking to, WHAT he promises, WHERE this happens, and WHY he speaks.
tips: The disciples are in Jerusalem after Jesus' last supper
Jesus promises to prepare a place for them in the Father's house
This happens to reassure them of his return and the coming of the Spirit

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: Jesus' declaration as the way (v11), Thomas' question (v5), or the promise of the Spirit (v16-17)?
tips: Jesus' declaration 'I am the way, and the truth, and the life' is a profound identity statement that defines the path to God
Thomas' question reveals the disciples' anxiety about the unknown future, which Jesus addresses with clarity
The promise of the Spirit as 'another Helper' (v16) provides comfort in the absence of Jesus

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was John trying to communicate to all believers through this passage?
tips: To assure believers that Jesus is the only way to the Father, providing both present assurance and future hope
To emphasize that Jesus' physical departure is not a loss but a preparation for eternal dwelling with God
To reveal that seeing Jesus is equivalent to seeing the Father, so believers have complete access to God through Him

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The concept of 'preparing a place' in heaven, the statement that 'no one comes to the Father except through me', or the idea of the Spirit as a 'Helper'?
tips: 'Preparing a place' (v2) refers to Christ's future work in the heavenly realm, not a physical house on earth
The phrase 'no one comes to the Father except through me' (v6) means that salvation is exclusively through Christ, not by human effort
The Spirit is described as 'another Helper' (v16) to be with believers forever, which is a promise of ongoing guidance

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply this week by trusting Christ as the way to the Father in a situation where you feel lost?
tips: Identify one area where you feel uncertain about God's plan (e.g., relationships, work, health) and pray for clarity through Christ
Practice the peace that Jesus offers by not letting your heart be troubled (v13) in your daily decisions
Share your trust in Christ as the way with one person this week, like Thomas did with Jesus

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God that He is the way, the truth, and the life. Ask for the courage to follow Him when the path is unclear.
tips: Thank God for Jesus as the only way to the Father
Pray for the Spirit to guide you in your current struggles
Ask for peace that the world cannot give (v14) in your heart

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read John 15:1-17 aloud, paying attention to the repetition of 'I am' and the phrase 'abide in me' in verses 5-6.
tips: Notice the phrase 'I am the true vine' appears in verse 1
The word 'abide' is used 4 times in this chapter (v.1, 5, 9, 10)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO Jesus is in this passage, WHAT He says about believers, WHERE this relationship exists, and WHY it matters for our lives.
tips: Jesus identifies Himself as the true vine (v.1)
Believers are the branches that must abide in Him (v.5)
This relationship is for fruit-bearing and to overcome the world (v.18-19)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: Jesus' declaration as the true vine (v.1), the call to abide (v.4-5), or the promise of fruit (v.8)?
tips: The phrase 'I am the true vine' (v.1) is a powerful metaphor for Christ's unique role in salvation
The command to 'abide in me' (v.4) is a call to ongoing relationship, not a one-time event
The promise that 'if you abide in me... you will bear much fruit' (v.8) shows the result of obedience

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was John trying to communicate to all believers through this passage about their relationship with Christ?
tips: John emphasizes that without Christ, believers cannot produce fruit (v.5)
The vine and branch metaphor shows Christ's active role in the believer's life
This passage addresses the believer's identity and purpose in Christ

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The meaning of 'abide', why pruning is necessary, or the concept of bearing fruit?
tips: 'Abide' (Greek: 'katast') means to remain in a close, active relationship with Christ, not just a passive state
Pruning (v.2) is a necessary process of removal of unproductive parts to encourage more fruit
Bearing fruit (v.8) is not about quantity but quality of spiritual growth and witness

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply the concept of 'abiding in Christ' to your life this week? What specific action will you take to stay connected to Him?
tips: Identify one area where you feel disconnected from Christ (e.g., prayer, Bible study)
Commit to spend 10 minutes daily in prayer and reflection with Christ
Pray for the Holy Spirit to help you 'abide' and bear fruit

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for being the true vine and ask for help to abide in Him.
tips: Thank God for Jesus as the true vine who provides life and purpose
Pray for the strength to resist the world and remain in Christ
Ask for the Holy Spirit to help you bear fruit through your actions and words

chapters.chapterTitle: The Spirit of Truth Will Come

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read John 16:1-28 aloud, paying attention to the phrases 'the Helper will come' (v12), 'sorrow turns to joy' (v20), and 'the Spirit of truth' (v13).
tips: Note the repetition of 'in a little while' (v19, 20) to show the nearness of the Spirit's coming
Pay attention to the contrast between current sorrow and future joy (v20-22)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO Jesus is testing, WHAT He commands, WHERE this happens, and WHY He speaks this way.
tips: Include the disciples' current persecution (v12-13)
Note that the Spirit of truth will convict the world (v8-11)
Describe the transition from sorrow to joy (v20-22)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the Spirit of truth convicting the world (v8-11), the sorrow turning to joy (v20), or the disciples' future confidence in Christ's name (v15).
tips: The Spirit of truth will convict the world of sin, righteousness, and judgment (v8-11) - this shows the Spirit's universal work
The image of sorrow turning to joy like a woman in labor (v20) - it's a powerful metaphor for the transition from pain to birth (of the Spirit)
The promise that they will ask in Christ's name (v15) - this shows the disciples' growing confidence in Him

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was John trying to communicate to all believers through this passage?
tips: John emphasizes that the coming of the Spirit is crucial for believers to have truth and peace
The Spirit's work in convicting the world and guiding believers into truth is a response to Christ's sacrifice
Despite tribulation, Christ has overcome the world (v18) so believers have hope

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The term 'Helper' (Parakletos), the transition from sorrow to joy, or the scope of 'the world'?
tips: 'Helper' (Parakletos) in Greek means 'one who is called to help' but here it refers to the Holy Spirit, not a human helper
The metaphor of sorrow turning to joy (v20) is a woman in labor - it's painful but leads to birth (of the Spirit and of the believer's hope)
'The world' in v8 refers to the sinful, rebellious human society that the Spirit will convict, not just the physical world

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply the theme of sorrow turning to joy (v20) to your current situation?
tips: Identify a recent sorrow (e.g., failure, loss) and pray for the Spirit of truth to bring joy through Christ
Ask God to help you see the coming of the Spirit in your life as a source of hope
Practice trusting that Christ has overcome the world (v18) so you don't let sorrow define you

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray for the Spirit of truth to come and guide you into the joy of Christ.
tips: Thank God for sending the Spirit of truth who convicts the world of sin
Ask for the Spirit to help you understand and apply the truth in your life
Pray that your sorrow turns to joy as you trust Christ has overcome the world

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read John 18:1-28 aloud, paying attention to the dialogue between Jesus and the soldiers in verses 4-6, and Peter's actions in verses 10-11.
tips: Notice Jesus' declaration 'I am he' in verse 4
Pay attention to the emotional shift when Peter draws his sword and cuts the ear (verse 11)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO is arrested, WHAT Jesus says when they seek Him, WHERE the arrest takes place, and WHY Jesus submits to the arrest.
tips: Include the three-day journey to the garden (v1-2)
Note Peter's action of cutting the ear (v10) and his subsequent denial (v25-27)
Describe Jesus' statement about His kingdom not being of this world (v37)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: Jesus' declaration 'I am he' (v4), Jesus telling Peter to put away the sword (v11), or Peter's three denials (v25-27)?
tips: Jesus' declaration 'I am he' shows His divine identity and authority
Peter's three denials highlight the cost of discipleship and the need for forgiveness
Jesus' command to put away the sword emphasizes His submission to the Father's will

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was John trying to communicate to all believers through this passage about Jesus' submission to arrest?
tips: John emphasizes Jesus' voluntary submission to the Father's will (the cup of suffering)
This passage shows Jesus' kingdom is not of this worldHe came to bear witness to the truth
The arrest and trial highlight the cost of following Christ and the need for discipleship

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The meaning of 'I am he', why Jesus drinks the cup, or Peter's three denials?
tips: In Hebrew, 'I am' (Ego eimi) is a divine name (YHWH) but Jesus uses it to claim authority
'Drink the cup' refers to the cup of suffering that Jesus will face on the cross
Peter's denials were a result of fear and a test of his faith, not a permanent rejection of Christ

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: Jesus drank the cup of suffering and Peter denied Him. What situation requires you to trust God's provision and avoid denial this week?
tips: Consider an area where you are holding back from full obedience
How can you practice being faithful despite fear (like Jesus' submission)?
Ask God to strengthen your trust in His provision when facing the cup of suffering

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for Jesus' voluntary submission to arrest. Ask for strength to face the cup of suffering and avoid denial.
tips: Thank God for Jesus' identity as the divine Son who says 'I am he'
Pray for forgiveness for when you deny Christ in your fears
Ask God to help you drink the cup of suffering for His glory

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read John 20:1-31 aloud, paying attention to the dialogue between Jesus and Mary Magdalene (v.11-18) and the appearance to Thomas (v.24-29).
tips: Notice the emotional shift in Mary Magdalene's response: from weeping to recognition (v.11-13)
Pay attention to the phrase 'My Lord and my God' (v.28) and its significance
Note the repeated emphasis on the resurrection as proof of Jesus' divinity (v.29)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (Jesus and the disciples), WHAT (the resurrection appearances), WHERE (the tomb and the disciples' meeting place), and WHY (to establish belief in Jesus as the Christ).
tips: Include Mary Magdalene's visit to the tomb and her encounter with Jesus (v.11-13)
Note Peter and the other disciple entering the tomb and seeing the linen cloths (v.11-12)
Highlight Thomas' initial refusal to believe and his later confession (v.24-28)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: Mary Magdalene's recognition of Jesus (v.12-13), Thomas' confession (v.28), or Jesus' statement about blessedness (v.29)?
tips: The moment Mary Magdalene recognizes Jesus by name shows the personal nature of the resurrection
Thomas' confession 'My Lord and my God' demonstrates the depth of faith that comes from physical evidence
Jesus' statement 'blessed are those who believe without seeing' emphasizes the importance of faith over sight

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was John trying to communicate to all believers through this passage?
tips: John emphasizes that Jesus' resurrection is the ultimate proof of His divinity and victory over death
The passage shows that the resurrection appearances were designed to lead to belief in Jesus as the Christ
The conclusion about 'these signs' being written to bring belief underscores the purpose of the resurrection for the church

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The empty tomb, the initial failure of recognition by Mary Magdalene, and Thomas' requirement for physical evidence?
tips: The empty tomb is a sign of the resurrection, but the stone being moved by angels (as per context) shows the tomb was empty
Mary's failure to recognize Jesus initially is a natural response to the emotional trauma of the tomb, but Jesus' personal address breaks through
Thomas' requirement for physical evidence is a common human response to the inexplicable, but Jesus' response shows that faith without sight is blessed

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply the truth that 'blessed are those who believe without seeing' (v.29) this week?
tips: Identify a situation where you have been waiting for physical proof before believing
Pray for the faith to trust in God's promises without requiring visible evidence
Consider how you can be a witness to others with faith that doesn't require physical signs

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God that He has risen and is alive. Ask for the faith to believe without seeing.
tips: Thank God for the resurrection and the promise of eternal life
Pray for courage to believe in Jesus even when the evidence seems absent
Ask God to help you recognize Jesus in your life and in the lives of others

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read John 21:1-25 aloud, focusing on the emotional shift from Peter's despair to restoration in verses 15-17.
tips: Notice the threefold repetition of 'Do you love me?' (vv. 15-17)
Pay attention to Peter's immediate response 'I love you' (v.15)
The phrase 'follow me' (v.22) carries urgent authority

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO is restored, WHAT Jesus commands, WHERE it happens, and WHY this appears after the resurrection.
tips: Include the disciples' night of fishing without success (vv.3-4)
Note Peter's threefold denial (John 18:25-27) and his restoration here
Describe the charcoal fire with fish and bread (vv.9-10)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: Peter's realization (v.15), the threefold commission (v.15-17), or Jesus' command to 'follow me' (v.22)?
tips: Peter's immediate confession 'I love you' (v.15) shows deep repentance and restoration
The threefold question and answer (v.15-17) symbolizes complete restoration after threefold denial
Jesus' command to 'feed my sheep' (v.16) is a call to shepherd the church

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was John trying to communicate to all believers through this passage?
tips: Christ restores the believer after failure and commissions them to shepherd the church
This passage shows the Lord's authority and love are sufficient for restoration
The threefold commission ties Peter's restoration to the ongoing mission of the church

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The threefold commission, the meaning of 'feed my sheep', or the command to 'follow me' in the context of Peter's restoration?
tips: The threefold repetition addresses Peter's threefold denial (John 18:25-27) and shows complete restoration
'Feed my sheep' is a metaphor for leading and caring for the church, not literal feeding
The command to 'follow me' (v.22) calls Peter to discipleship he had previously abandoned (v.18)

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply the commission to 'feed my sheep' in your life this week?
tips: Identify one person in your community who needs care and reach out to them
Reflect on how you can shepherd others in your family or church community
Pray for the courage to follow Christ even when it's costly, as Peter did

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for restoring you after failure and calling you to shepherd the church.
tips: Thank God for restoring you after your failures and calling you to service
Ask for the strength to follow Christ even when it's costly
Pray for the gift of shepherding others as Christ has called you
